definition: to deceive/to cheat/to hoodwink/to make a wild guess
Mongol ethnic group/abbr. for Mongolia 蒙古國|蒙古国[Meng3 gu3 guo2]/Taiwan pr. [Meng2]
to cover/ignorant/to suffer (misfortune)/to receive (a favor)/to cheat

sentences.chinese: 不要让你的知识蒙蔽了自己。

sentences.english: And don't let the aurora borealis fool you.
sentences.chinese: 所以不要被北极光给蒙蔽了双眼。

sentences.english: But most blacks have not been blinded by race.
sentences.chinese: 但大多数的黑人没有被种族蒙蔽眼睛。

sentences.english: He hath also broken my teeth with gravel stones, he hath covered me with ashes.
sentences.chinese: 他又用沙石碜断我的牙，用灰尘将我蒙蔽。

sentences.english: You're renumber one ally just cheating yourself if you cheat in a test.
sentences.chinese: 你要在考试中作弊其实就是蒙蔽你自己。

sentences.english: This is clearly designed to befuddle the public.
sentences.chinese: 这显然是为了蒙蔽舆论。

sentences.english: India's anti-LTTE policy blinds their vision.
sentences.chinese: 印度的反泰米尔政策蒙蔽自己的视野。

sentences.english: This curse can blind managers to opportunities and threats.
sentences.chinese: 这一诅咒会在机遇和危险面前蒙蔽那些经理的双眼。

sentences.english: Unobscured by the dust of history.
The eye also of the adulterer waiteth for the twilight, saying, No eye shall see me: and disguises his face.
sentences.chinese: 奸夫等候黄昏，说，必无眼能见我，就把脸蒙蔽。

sentences.english: First, we are not blindsided by illusions.
sentences.chinese: 首先，我们不再被错觉蒙蔽。

sentences.english: So it is no wonder companies are afraid. But, as so often happens, fear has clouded their judgement.
sentences.chinese: 但常见的情况是，恐惧蒙蔽了他们的判断力。

sentences.english: She was blinded by the glitter and the glamour of her own life.
sentences.chinese: 她被自己的生活中表面上的光鲜与奢华所蒙蔽。

sentences.english: Our intense emotion makes us an again heavy is hoodwink .
sentences.chinese: 我们的激情又使我们一次次重受蒙蔽。

sentences.english: Hide them in the dust together; and bind their faces in secret.
sentences.chinese: 将他们一同隐藏在尘土中，把他们的脸蒙蔽在隐密处。

sentences.english: Reality can dawn only on an unclouded mind.
sentences.chinese: 实相只能显示给未受蒙蔽的心灵。

definition: variant of 矇騙|蒙骗[meng1 pian4]
to make a fool out of/to fool/to dupe
lit. to be muddled in the brain (idiom); fig. excited and unable to act rationally/to go to one's head
lit. to be muddled in the brain (idiom); fig. excited and unable to act rationally/to go to one's head
see through (a person, scheme, trick etc)
to understand thoroughly/to see beyond the facade/to see through (sb)
to rock/to sway/to flicker (e.g. of lights reflected on water)/to flutter (e.g. of a flag)/to trick sb into doing sth/to dupe/to con
to listen to information/to get the news/to believe what one hears
